title: TV Pick of the Day: Ted Hughes: Stronger Than Death (BBC Two),...
text:
Comments (0) 
The BBC is currently celebrating 21 years of National Poetry Day with a series of fascinating documentaries and dramas. 
"This autumn, BBC Two and BBC Four are putting poets and poetry at the heart of the schedule with an ambitious range of content which demonstrates the unique and distinctive way in which the two channels work together," says Kim Shillinglaw, controller of both channels. 
"BBC Two brings viewers a landmark piece in peak time about one of our most celebrated poets, Ted Hughes, and then BBC Four enables the audience to take their interest further with a wide range of entertaining and expert content." 
The Hughes documentary is undoubtedly the highlight of the short season; it paints a portrait of this remarkably talented man, one whose career has, at times, been overshadowed by personal tragedies. 
Hughes was born in Mytholmroyd in West Yorkshire in 1930, the youngest of three children of a joiner, but moved to Mexborough in the southern part of the county at the age of seven when his parents took over a local newsagent's. 
It was there that his desire to become a writer began. At the town's grammar school, he was encouraged by several teachers, including John Fisher; he also mentored future poet Harold Massingham, who attended the school at the same time as Hughes. 
After his national service, Hughes studied at Cambridge University. It was at a party in the city in February 1956 that he met American writer Sylvia Plath, who became his first wife just months later. 
"I went to this little celebration and that's actually where we met," said Plath, during an interview with the BBC. "Then we saw a great deal of each other. Ted came back to Cambridge and suddenly we found ourselves getting married a few months later. 
"We kept writing poems to each other. Then it just grew out of that, I guess, a feeling that we both were writing so much and having such a fine time doing it, we decided that this should keep on." 
Their happiness was short-lived. They had two children, Frieda and Nicholas, but in 1963, after years of battling depression and several previous suicide attempts, Plath took her own life. She was separated from Hughes at the time due to his affair with their lodger, Assia Wevill, who would also commit suicide - simultaneously killing her young daughter Shura - six years later. 
Hughes was vilified by some following these events, but he remained silent on the subject, particularly that of Plath, until the release of his best-selling book Birthday Letters in 1998. By that time he had terminal cancer, and died later the same year. 
Hughes spent the last 14 years of his life as poet laureate, and is widely regarded as one of the most gifted poets of the 20th century. 
The documentary shows that the interconnection between what happened during his life and his creativity were at the heart of his work, while fellow writers offer their opinions on his output. But of most interest will be an interview with Frieda Hughes who, in her first such TV appearance, talks in-depth about her father.
